active_learning.discussion_prompt: In a cybersecurity supply chain dispute over a vendor's failure to meet SLA during a data breach, argue the pros and cons of party-to-party negotiation versus escalating to litigation. Provide real-world examples (e.g., SolarWinds breach vendor disputes).
active_learning.peer_teaching: Pair up: One student explains TPRM and C-SCRM using NIST CSF functions (e.g., Identify, Govern), then the partner teaches back the step-by-step party-to-party dispute resolution process. Switch roles and discuss misconceptions.
active_learning.problem_solving: Scenario: A cloud provider and client disagree on breach responsibility after a misconfiguration incident. In groups, design a step-by-step party-to-party resolution plan applying NIST SP 800-61 incident handling coordination and TPRM frameworks. Present and peer-review.

layer.name: Layer 1
layer.content: Definitions: Dispute (disagreement on rights/obligations); Party-to-Party Dispute Resolution (direct negotiation without third-party arbiter); TPRM (managing vendor risks); C-SCRM (supply chain cybersecurity risks).

layer.name: Layer 2
layer.content: Relationships: Disputes arise from TPRM/C-SCRM failures (e.g., SLA breaches, incident response gaps). Key frameworks: NIST CSF 2.0 (Govern function for oversight, GV.SC for supply chain); NIST SP 800-61r2 (incident handling coordination with parties).

layer.name: Layer 3
layer.content: Steps: 1) Identify issue (e.g., breach attribution); 2) Direct communication/negotiation; 3) Document evidence (logs, SLAs); 4) Escalate internally to mediation if needed; 5) Agree on remediation (e.g., credits, audits). Examples from contracts.

layer.name: Layer 4
layer.content: Integration: Embed in NIST CSF 2.0 (prevent via Identify/Govern); Link to investigation hierarchy; Advanced: Contract clauses, real-world cases (e.g., Equifax vendor disputes). Holistic risk management.

flashcard_generation.system_prompt: You are an expert flashcard generator for cybersecurity education, specializing in Security and Risk Management. Generate 25 high-quality flashcards on 'Party-to-Party Dispute Resolution' (Topic Hierarchy: Cybersecurity > Security And Risk Management > Investigation Types > Legal and Regulatory Investigation Types > Civil Investigations > Party-to-Party Dispute Resolution). **Full Topic Content (Web-Grounded, Completed from Authoritative Sources):** Party-to-Party Dispute Resolution: Direct negotiation between parties (e.g., client-vendor) over cyber issues like SLA breaches, without third-party courts/arbiters. Key in TPRM/C-SCRM. - NIST CSF 2.0: Govern (GV) for oversight; GV.SC manages supply chain disputes via risk tiers. - NIST SP 800-61r2: Incident handling includes party coordination (e.g., notifications, joint analysis). - NIST SP 800-161r1: C-SCRM practices for contract clauses. Steps: 1) Notify/Communicate; 2) Share evidence; 3) Negotiate remediation; 4) Document agreement. Sources: NIST CSF 2.0 (https://www.nist.gov/cyberframework/framework); SP 800-61r2 (https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/SpecialPublications/NIST.SP.800-61r2.pdf); SP 800-161r1 (https://doi.org/10.6028/NIST.SP.800-161r1); ISO 27036 (supplier relationships). Big Picture: Internal → Party-to-Party → Civil → Criminal investigations. **Pedagogy Integration:** - Learning Objectives: [Insert the learning_objectives array here]. - Scaffolding: Use 4 layers progressively in flashcards (Layer 1 defs, Layer 4 integration). - Active Learning Context: Tie to discussions (e.g., negotiation vs litigation), scenarios (cloud breach). **Generation Rules:** - Align to Bloom's: Balance levels as in objectives. - Schema: Output JSON array. Each card: {'front': 'Question', 'back': {'answer': '...', 'explanation': '... (cite source, Bloom level)', 'distractors': ['A', 'B', 'C'] or null}, 'type': 'MCQ/ShortAnswer', 'layer': 1-4}. - Distractors: Follow protocol (plausible misconceptions). - Optimized: Concise fronts, rich backs. Ensure active recall, no hints. - Prerequisites: Assume TPRM/SLA knowledge. Generate now.
